subject: Welcome to Nemo - Your Newsletter Aggregator!
content:
üê† Welcome to Nemo!

This is an example newsletter to show you how the system works.

Once you start forwarding real newsletters, they'll appear here automatically.

Features:

  • Search and filter newsletters
  • Mobile-friendly interface
  • Expandable content view
  • Today's newsletters highlighted

To get started, forward your newsletters to the webhook endpoint and watch them populate here!

Happy newsletter hunting! üé£

subject: $50M could save these homes ‚Äî if the budget passes
content:
A home repair program faces a tough road ahead

View this email in your web browser.

This week's newsletter is made possible byreaders like you& our sponsors.

$50M could save these homes ‚Äî if the budget passes

As Pa.'s housing crisis deepens, lawmakers are once again pushing for a $50M home repair program to help residents stay in their homes. Backed by Gov. Shapiro, the proposal faces a tough road amid ongoing budget talks. Could this be the breakthrough?

Read Aaron Moselle's report ‚Äî and share your thoughts: planphilly@whyy.org.

subject: Free-market economics is working surprisingly well
content:
Which economic approach works depends a lot on where you start from.

One area of seeming bipartisan consensus in America over the past decade is the idea that free-market economics ‚Äî or "neoliberalism" ‚Äî has failed, and that our economic system needs to be overhauled. Leftists have always believed this, of course, and in recent years they've been joined by more mainstream progressives like the folks at the Hewlett Foundation. On the right, thanks to Trump, tariffs and immigration restriction have overthrown free trade as the reigning orthodoxy.

And in case this wasn't clear, I have been one of the voices calling for a new economic system! For years I criticized free-market ideology, fretted about the decline of the Rust Belt, expressed suspicion about free trade, and called for industrial policy to revive manufacturing. I wrote many times that the Biden Administration's industrial policies represented a needed break with the dogmas of the past, and that Trump had enabled that needed shift by destroying the political consensus for free trade. I'm constantly warning that without attention to strategic industries, America and its allies will lose a war to China.

There's a good chance I'll end up advising the Hewlett Foundation in some capacity on what our next economic ideology ought to be. Despite being elected "Chief Neoliberal Shill" in a humorous online poll back in 2018, I was never an actual neoliberal or a free-markets kind of guy. So to be clear, when I say that criticism of free markets has been overdone, I'm partly talking to myself.

A couple of months ago, horrified by Trump's tariff policies, I wrote an apology to libertarians, admitting that I had failed to see the political usefulness of their project in terms of maintaining economic sanity on the Right.

But it's not just the political benefits of free markets that have been undersold; I think the purely economic advantages are also too often ignored. Exhibit A is Javier Milei's track record in Argentina.

A year and a half ago, when Milei was elected President of Argentina, a bunch of left-wing economists warned darkly that his radical free-market program would lead to economic devastation. But so far, his policies - including deep fiscal austerity, deregulation, and currency reform - have actually helped stabilize Argentina's economy after years of crisis.

Inflation, which was spiraling out of control, has come down significantly. While still high by developed country standards, the monthly inflation rate has dropped from over 25% to around 2.4%. The poverty rate, after an initial spike, is now falling as the economy recovers. And in a surprising turn, the removal of rent control has led to a 195% increase in rental housing supply in Buenos Aires, with prices falling about 10%.

This doesn't mean free-market policies are always the answer everywhere. The reality is that different economic approaches work better in different contexts. Countries need to find the right balance between markets and government intervention based on their specific circumstances. But Argentina's experience under Milei does suggest that free-market policies can be more effective than their critics claim, especially in countries that have veered too far toward statism.

The key is pragmatism rather than ideology - being willing to adjust policies based on what actually works rather than rigidly adhering to any one economic doctrine. As with most things in life, the truth lies somewhere in the middle.

subject: Latest in AI and Machine Learning
content:
The Latest Breakthroughs in AI

This week's developments in artificial intelligence are changing how we think about machine learning. From new language models to computer vision advancements, the pace of innovation shows no signs of slowing down.

  • New multimodal AI systems that can understand both text and images
  • Breakthroughs in energy-efficient AI training
  • The rise of AI-assisted creative tools
  • Ethical considerations in AI development

Stay tuned for more updates as we continue to cover the rapidly evolving world of artificial intelligence.

subject: The Future of Work in an AI World
content:
